Caption: Fig. 1. A HEDA with 5 attributes ({QA, QB,CA, QC,CB}) using size to encode their values: green for categorical; gray for quantitative attributes.

Fig. 2. Arc diagram extended with HEDA. This dataset is lawyers in a firm and their relationships. The attributes shown are: age, status, gender, office, yearsinFirm, practice, and law-school. As indicated by the check in the query panel, the lawyers are ordered according to their age.
Fig. 3. Scatterplot-HEDA visualization of an automobile dataset. HEDA has been applied as an extension on both X and Y axes.
Fig. 4. Designs for HEDA applied to a variety of familiar visualization types from the D3 gallery.

Fig. 7. A Line Chart extended with HEDA. The original line chart, showing temperatures in ascending order by date (top), is reordered according to weather, then data points within each weather category are locally reordered by descending date (bottom).

Fig. 5. A Sunburst Tree extended with HEDA showing the possibilities offered with local hierarchical reordering. Some nodes have their children reordered according to the binary attribute in black, others according to the continuous attribute in gray.

Fig. 5. A Sunburst Tree extended with HEDA showing the possibilities offered with local hierarchical reordering. Some nodes have their children reordered according to the binary attribute in black, others according to the continuous attribute in gray.
Fig. 9. Among the lawyers who are partners, only three are female and they all work in the Boston office.
Fig. 8. The lawyers are ordered by their status and then age. Left lawyers are associates, and the right ones are partners.
